choices.text: Posterior interosseous nerve

questions.text: Identify the nerve involved in this test: (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Median nerve

 

SPECIAL TESTS FOR MEDIAN NERVE INJURY

 

  • Pen Test:
    • Test: Patient keeps his/her hand flat on the table and at the same time, examiner brings a pen above the thumb.
    • Interpretation: Patient tries to touch the pen by abduction the thumb and examiner feels the tendon of abductor pollicis brevis (APB) at the wrist. Patient fails to touch in APB paralysis and examiner will not be able to palpate the tendon.
    • Note: Median nerve invariably and exclusively supply APB.

 

 

  • Pointing Index Sign / Ochsner’s Clasping / Benediction Test:
    • Test: Patient clasps his both hand together.
    • Interpretation: The index finger fails to flex in median nerve injury and it points outward as pointing index.
    • Note: It occur in high median nerve palsy where flexor digitorum superficialis and lateral half of flexor digitorum profundus gets involved.

 

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Ulnar nerve. Special tests for ulnar nerve injury are:

 

  • Froment’s sign:
    • Test: The patient is asked to make a strong pinch between the thumb and index finger and grip a flat object such as a piece of paper between the thumb and index finger. The examiner then attempts to pull the object out of the patient’s hands.
    • Interpretation: There is weakness of the adductor pollicis innervated by the ulnar nerve which would keep the IP joint relatively straight; instead, the FPL muscle, which is innervated by the median nerve is substituted for the AP and will cause the IP joint to go into a hyperflexed position.

 

 

  • Wartenberg’s sign:
    • Test: The patient’s places wrist in neutral and forearm in full pronation and is instructed to perform full extension of all the fingers. Once digits are extended, patient is asked to fully abduct and then adduct all fingers.
    • Interpretation: A positive sign is indicated with the observation of abduction of the 5th digit, with the inability to adduct the 5th finger when extended.

 

 

  • Egawa’s sign:
    • Test: The patient flexes the middle digit & then alternately deviates the finger radially & ulnarly.
    • Interpretation: If the patient is unable to do this Egawa’s sign, the interossei are affected.

 

Option C. Posterior interosseous nerve. The patient may exhibit weakness with finger extension. When asked to make a fist, the wrist may deviate radially due to extensor carpi ulnaris weakness. Depending on injury severity there may be a positive Tinel sign at the site of injury.

 

Option D. Musculocutaneous nerve. Check strength of Biceps Brachii, Corocobrachialis and Brachialis muscles. Check sensation on lateral forearm.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The test image shown in the question is the Pen Test, which is done to diagnose median nerve injury.

choices.text: Knuckle bender splint; Ulnar Nerve Palsy
Dynamic cock up splint; Radial Nerve Palsy
Turn buckle splint; Volkmann’s Ischemic Contracture
Knuckle bender splint; Median Nerve Palsy

questions.text: Correctly match the statement regarding the splint shown in image:(NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Dynamic cock up splint; Radial Nerve Palsy

 

  • Cock-up splint is used for radial nerve palsy.

 

 

RADIAL NERVE INJURIES

 

  • Most common nerve damaged in human body.
  • Most common cause: Fracture of shaft of Humerus
  • Shaft of Humerus divided into 3 parts:
    • Upper 1/3rd
    • Middle 1/3rd
    • Lower 1/3rd: Radial nerve injured (50%)
       
  • Holstein Lewis sign: Radial nerve injury in lower 1/3rd fracture of shaft of Humerus
  • Paralysis of ECRL & ECRB will cause loss of wrist, thumb and finger extension, leading to Wrist drop.
  • Wrist drop occurs in low radial nerve palsy, which spares the elbow and wrist extension.
  • There is also loss of sensation over the dorsum of 1st web space.

 

 

 

  • Treatment:
    • Treatment is usually conservative, which includes analgesic medications like NSAIDs; corticosteroid injections; physiotherapy; and immobilization with cock-up splints for 2-4 weeks.
    • The patient recovers within 4 months.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Knuckle bender splint; Ulnar nerve palsy. Knuckle bender splint is a finger flexion splint which flexes the MCP joint of all digits without blocking the IP joint or wrist joint motion. it assists the intrinsic muscle weakness. It is used in cases ulnar nerve palsy (ulnar claw hand) and median nerve palsy.

 

 

Option C. Turn buckle splint; Volkmann’s ischemic contracture. Turn buckle splint is used to produce gradual stretching over the contracted joint. It is used to treat stiff elbow and Volkmann’s ischemic contracture.

 

 

Option D. Knuckle bender splint; Median nerve palsy. Knuckle bender splint is a finger flexion splint which flexes the MCP joint of all digits without blocking the IP joint or wrist joint motion. it assists the intrinsic muscle weakness. It is used in cases ulnar nerve palsy (ulnar claw hand) and median nerve palsy.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The given image in the question is a dynamic cock-up splint, which is used in cases of radial nerve injuries (wrist drop).

questions.text: Identify the drug used to treat the condition shown below: (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Anti-tubercular therapy

 

  • The image showing a plaque with one margin extending & other margin healing with scarring (Asymmetrical lesion), this favors to the diagnosis of lupus vulgaris, which is treated using anti-tubercular drugs.
  • It is the most common cutaneous tuberculosis in adults in India.
  • It occurs in previously sensitized hosts with good immunity.
  • Granulomas with little to no caseation can be seen on histology.

 

Lupus Vulgaris

 

  • Lupus vulgaris is a chronic form of skin TB seen in patients with moderate immunity to TB bacilli
  • It is seen more common in females.

 

Pathogenesis:

 

  • It occurs due to hematogenous, lymphatic, or contiguous spread from elsewhere in the body, or from exogenous inoculation. It occurs in previously sensitized hosts with good immunity, hence Paucibacillary.

 

Clinical features

 

  • It presents as single or few lesions which are well demarcated, annular plaques which extend centrifugally. Periphery show erythematous deep-seated nodules which on diascopy may stand out as apple jelly nodules as seen in the image below.

 

 

  •  They are most commonly seen in buttocks, upper extremities, and face. Center is depigmented with paper-thin scar with nodules.
  • Papules may recur on the scarred areas, which enlarge and coalesce. This leads to the formation of large, firm, elevated plaques.

 

Diagnosis

 

  • Histologic examination & a positive culture for M. tuberculosis/ bovis confirm the diagnosis
  • Most prominent histopathologic feature: Typical granulomas with scanty or absent caseation.

 

Complication

 

  • Secondary scarring & squamous cell carcinomas may develop rarely.

 

Treatment:

Anti-tubercular drugs.

 

CLASSIFICATION OF CUTANEOUS TUBERCULOSIS IS BASED ON THE MODE OF ACQUISITION:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Topical steroids therapy:

  • This is not the appropriate treatment for lupus vulgaris.
  • Topical steroids are used for inflammatory conditions, and while they may reduce inflammation and symptoms temporarily, they do not address the underlying mycobacterial infection that causes lupus vulgaris.

 

Option B. Anti-leprosy treatment:

  • Although leprosy is also caused by a mycobacterium (Mycobacterium leprae) and anti-leprosy drugs are used to treat it, the clinical features described do not match leprosy.
  • Moreover, the treatment regimens for leprosy and tuberculosis are different.

 

Option C. Anti-fungal therapy:

  • Fungal infections can present with skin lesions, but the description of the lesion as characteristic of lupus vulgaris does not fit a fungal infection.
  • Anti-fungal therapy would not be effective against mycobacterial infections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lupus vulgaris is a form of cutaneous tuberculosis characterized by irregular plaques that show progression at one margin and healing with scarring at another, and to understand that the appropriate treatment is a multi-drug anti-tubercular therapy regimen.

 

References:

 

Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition page no 27.21-27.23, 32.35-32.36, 33.44-33.45

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lung Abscess

 

The image shows a cavity in the lung with an air-fluid level, which is characteristic of a lung abscess. A lung abscess typically appears as a localized collection of pus within the lung, caused by microbial infection, and is usually associated with an air-fluid level within a thick-walled cavity. This radiologic appearance is a hallmark of a lung abscess and distinguishes it from other conditions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. TB (Tuberculosis): Tuberculosis can present with thick-walled cavities but typically does not show a distinct air-fluid level as seen in a lung abscess. TB lesions are often more irregular and do not exhibit the same characteristic air-fluid line.

 

Option C. Fungal Pneumonia: Fungal pneumonia often presents with multiple nodules and may display a "halo sign" (nodules surrounded by ground-glass opacity). It does not typically present as a single cavity with an air-fluid level.

 

Option D. Hydropneumothorax: This condition is characterized by the presence of both air and fluid in the pleural space, often leading to a visible air-fluid level, but the appearance is generally over a larger portion of the hemithorax and not within a lung cavity itself. It appears more diffuse rather than localized like a lung abscess.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A lung abscess is identified by a cavity with an air-fluid level on imaging, differentiating it from other pulmonary conditions like TB, fungal infections, and hydropneumothorax.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman on oral contraceptives for the past 6 months presents with 6 weeks of amenorrhea. What would be the best method of assessing the gestational age of this patient? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Crown rump length by USG

 

Explanation:

 

Crown-Rump Length (CRL) by Ultrasound:

 

  • The most accurate method for determining gestational age in the first trimester is by measuring the Crown-Rump Length (CRL) on ultrasound. This method is reliable as it directly measures the embryo or fetus and provides a precise gestational age.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Adding 280 days to the Last Menstrual Period (LMP):

 

  • This method, known as Naegele’s rule, is commonly used but assumes a regular 28-day menstrual cycle and may not be accurate for women with irregular cycles or those using contraceptives.
  • It is less reliable in this patient who has been on oral contraceptives, which can alter the regularity of menstrual cycles.

 

Option C. Fundus Examination:

 

  • Palpation of the uterine fundus is a physical examination method to estimate gestational age. However, it is less accurate in the first trimester and typically used in the second and third trimesters.

 

Option D. Adding 256 days to the LMP:

 

  • This method is not standard practice and is less commonly used compared to adding 280 days to the LMP.
  • It would be even less reliable in this patient who has been on oral contraceptives.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most accurate method for determining gestational age in the first trimester is the measurement of Crown-Rump Length (CRL) on ultrasound.

 

Ref: Page no 475, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: Fimbriectomy is also known as? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Kroner’s procedure

 

Explanation:

 

Fimbriectomy is a method of tubal ligation where the fimbriated end of the Fallopian tube is ligated and excised. This technique is also known as Kroner’s procedure.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Pomeroy technique: In this method, the mid-isthmic portion of the Fallopian tube is elevated and then folded at the midpoint. One or two rapidly absorbable sutures are tied around the double thickness of the tube, and the folded portion is excised sharply.

 

Option B. Uchida's procedure: This involves ligating and excising the midportion of the Fallopian tube. The utero-tubal serosa is then hydro-dissected, and the proximal tubal stump is pulled into the mesosalpinx. The peritoneum is closed over the proximal cut end of the tube.

 

Option D. Irving's procedure: In this method, the midportion of the Fallopian tube is ligated and excised. The proximal tubal stump is inserted into an incision made into the myometrium and securely sutured to bury the proximal stump in the myometrium.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fimbriectomy, also known as Kroner's procedure, involves ligation and excision of the fimbriated end of the Fallopian tube.

 

Ref: Page no 497, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology, 6th edition

questions.text: A small child was playing with her maid where she rotated her by holding from arms. Immediately after, the child started crying. On examination, her forearm was pronated. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Pulled elbow

 

  • History of traction on elbow with forearm pronated is classical of pulled elbow.

 

PULLED ELBOW/NURSE MAID’S ELBOW

 

  • It is subluxation of radial head or more accurately subluxation of the annular (orbicular) ligament which slips up over the head of radius into the radio-capitellar joint.

 

 

  • Mechanism of Injury: Traction to elbow.
  • Clinical Features:
    • Maximum incidence in 1-4 years of age group.
    • The child holds the elbow in slight flexion with the forearm pronated.
    • X-rays are normal.
  • Treatment:
    • Reduced by flexing the elbow to 90° and rapidly and firmly rotating the forearm into full supination on outdoor basis without anaesthesia. 
    • Immobilization is not necessary.
    • Supination is a gravity-assisted movement and pulled elbow may be reduced spontaneously by gravity, but this may take time.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dislocation of elbow. Elbow Dislocations in the pediatric population usually occur in older children (10-15 years) and can be associated with elbow fractures such as medial epicondyle fractures. Male: female = 3:1. Very rare in younger children < 3 years old. Mechanism of injury is fall on an outstretched hand. Symptoms include painful and swollen elbow, attempts at motion are painful and restricted. On physical examination, the elbow is held in flexion, forearm appears to be shortened from the anterior and posterior view. On palpation, distal humerus creates a fullness within the antecubital fossa. Radiographs shows loss of radiocapitellar and ulnohumeral relationship but maintained radial and ulnar relationship. Treatment is usually closed reduction and brief immobilization for 1-2 weeks. 

 

 

Option C. Fracture head of radius. Radial head fractures are common injuries and may occur in association with dislocation of the elbow. In children, radial neck fractures are more common than radial head fractures. Classically, the head of radius should not be excised in children because it will interfere with the synchronous growth of radius and ulna, producing wrist and elbow deformity. It may lead to proximal radial migration and subluxation of inferior radio-ulnar joint, weakness of extremity and discomfort in distal radioulnar joint with heavy activities, and may produce cubitus valgus deformity.

 

 

Option D. Fracture coronoid process. Coronoid Fractures are traumatic elbow fractures that are generally pathognomonic for an episode of elbow instability. The patient presents with elbow deformity & swelling, elbow/forearm/wrist pain. On inspection & palpation, there is varus or valgus deformity, ecchymosis & swelling, and diffuse tenderness. The treatment involves brief immobilization, followed by early range of motion. 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

History of traction on elbow with forearm in pronation in a child < 4 years of age is a classical feature of pulled elbow.

choices.text: Spread of tumor to anterior chest wall

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman discovered a lump in her breast during a self-examination. She immediately scheduled an appointment with her primary care physician for further evaluation. On examination by the doctor this was noticed.  What is the cause for the following skin change? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Infiltration of subdermal lymphatics

 

  • When the subdermal lymphatic vessels, which are responsible for draining lymph fluid from the tissues, are infiltrated or blocked by cancer cells, it can cause edema or swelling in the skin.
  • This can lead to skin changes resembling the dimpled surface of an orange, known as "peau d'orange."
  • The infiltration of subdermal lymphatics with tumor cells leads to the appearance of skin thickening and pores becoming more prominent, which is characteristic of peau d'orange.

 

Other Options :

 

Option B. Infiltration of lactiferous duct: Infiltration or blockage of these ducts might lead to nipple retraction.

 

Option C. Involvement of Cooper's ligament: Cooper's ligaments are fibrous tissues that provide structural support to the breast. They help in maintaining the shape and position of the breast. Cancer can invade these ligaments and cause dimpling.

 

Option D. Spread of tumor to anterior chest wall: If a breast tumor spreads to the anterior chest wall, it can cause fixation of the breast to the chest, making the breast immobile.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Peau d'orange is a skin change indicative of underlying breast cancer where subdermal lymphatic infiltration leads to edema and skin dimpling resembling the surface of an orange.

questions.text: What is the odor of a mummified body? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Odorless

 

A mummified body is characterized by the absence of moisture, leading to its preservation. This process results in the body becoming dry and leathery, which eliminates the conditions necessary for the growth of bacteria responsible for producing foul odors.

 

Mummification:

 

  • Odor: Mummified bodies are odorless due to the absence of moisture, which inhibits bacterial growth and decomposition.
  • Appearance: The body becomes dry and leathery, preserving it in a desiccated state.

 

Comparison with Other Types of Decomposition:

 

  • Adipocere Formation:
    • Odor: An adipocere body has a foul, rancid smell similar to decomposing fats.
    • Formation: Adipocere, also known as "grave wax," forms when body fat undergoes a chemical transformation into a waxy substance, typically in moist environments.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pungent: This odor is might be present in cases of certain chemical exposures or other types of decomposition.

 

Option C. Putrid: This odor is characteristic of bodies undergoing typical decomposition, where bacterial activity produces foul-smelling gases.

 

Option D. Offensive: Similar to putrid, this term describes the unpleasant odors produced during the normal decomposition process.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A mummified body is odorless due to its dry and preserved state, an adipocere body which has foul rancid smell (like decomposing fats)

questions.text: Heller's operation is done for: (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Achalasia cardia

 

Heller's operation, also known as Heller myotomy, is a surgical procedure designed to treat achalasia. During this procedure, the surgeon makes a series of cuts into the thickened muscle of the LES to allow it to relax and improve the passage of food into the stomach. So, Heller's operation is indeed done for achalasia cardia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Carcinoma esophagus: Carcinoma of the esophagus refers to cancer that starts in the esophagus. While surgeries are often performed for esophageal cancer, Heller's operation specifically is not one of them. Instead, procedures like esophagectomy (removal of all or part of the esophagus) are performed for esophageal cancer.

 

Option C. Esophageal stricture: An esophageal stricture is a narrowing of the esophagus, which can lead to difficulty swallowing. It can result from various causes, including acid reflux or injuries to the esophagus. Esophageal dilatation (stretching of the esophagus using dilators) is commonly done for esophageal strictures.

 

Option D. Hypertrophic pyloric stenosis: Hypertrophic pyloric stenosis is a condition in infants where the muscle at the junction between the stomach and the small intestine (the pylorus) becomes enlarged, leading to obstruction. The treatment for this condition is a surgery called pyloromyotomy, where the thickened muscle is split to relieve the obstruction.

 

In conclusion, among the given options, Heller's operation is specifically done for achalasia cardia (Option A).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Heller's myotomy is a surgical procedure used to treat achalasia cardia by cutting the lower esophageal sphincter muscle to relieve obstruction and improve swallowing.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male who engaged in unprotected sexual intercourse develops urethral discharge one week later as shown in the given image below. What is the most likely causative organism for this condition? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Neisseria gonorrhea

 

The given image shows purulent urethral discharge that developed one week after unprotected sexual intercourse is suggestive of acute urethritis. The most likely causative organism for acute urethritis in males is Neisseria gonorrhea.

 

Purulent urethral discharge can be seen in gonorrhea caused by Neisseria gonorrhea or lymphogranuloma venerum caused by Chlamydia trachomatis.

 

Gonorrhea:

 

Gonorrhea is a disease acquired by sexual contact. The first step in infection is the infection of gonococci to the urethra or other mucosal surfaces. Pilli is involved in this adhesion. The cocci penetrate the intracellular spaces and reach subepithelial tissue by the third day of infection. The incubation period is 2-8 days. The major symptoms include urethral discharge and dysuria, usually without urinary frequency or urgency. The specific symptoms seen in males and females are as follows:

 

In males:

 

  • ﻿﻿The disease starts as acute urethritis. This infection may extend along the urethra to involve the prostate, seminal vesicles, and epididymis.
  • ﻿﻿Chronic urethritis may lead to stricture formation.
  • ﻿﻿The infection may spread to the periurethral tissues causing abscesses and multiple discharging sinuses (watercan perineum).

 

In females:

 

  • ﻿﻿The initial infection involves the cervix uteri and urethra which may extend to Bartholin glands, endometrium, and fallopian tubes.
  • ﻿﻿The vaginal mucosa is not usually affected in adults because the stratified squamous epithelium is resistant to infection by the cocci, and also because of the acidic pH of vaginal secretions.
  • ﻿﻿Pelvic inflammatory disease and salpingitis may lead to sterility.
  • ﻿﻿Rarely peritonitis may develop with perihepatic inflammation (Fitz Hugh Curtis syndrome)

 

Lab diagnosis:

 

The discharge is collected and subjected to Gram's stain which reveals gram-negative intracellular diplococci within phagocytes. Stuart's transport medium is used. Cultures can be obtained from chocolate agar or Mueller-Hinton agar. Specifically, Thayer-Martin agar is used to isolate Neisseria gonorrhoeae.

 

Treatment: Ceftriaxone (250mg, IM) single-dose + azithromycin 1 g PO, single-dose or doxycycline 100 mg PO BD for 7 days

 

The image below shows the Gram-stain of a urethral exudate showing typical intracellular gram-negative diplococci and pleomorphic extracellular gram-negative organisms

 

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Ureaplasma urealyticum is the second most common cause of non-gonococcal urethritis next to chlamydia. That is why the initial etiological agent under suspicion always remains gonorrhea.

 

Option C. Herpes Simplex will be associated with vesicular lesions.

 

Option D. Trichomonas vaginalis generally presents with a frothy discharge

 

Educational Objective

 

Neisseria gonorrhoeae is a significant cause of sexually transmitted infections, manifesting as acute urethritis with purulent discharge in males. Prompt diagnosis and treatment with appropriate antibiotics, such as a combination of ceftriaxone and azithromycin, are crucial to prevent complications and limit the spread of this highly contagious infection.

 

Non-gonococcal urethritis is caused by:

 

  • ﻿﻿Chlamydia trachomatis
  • ﻿﻿Ureaplasma urealyticum
  • ﻿﻿Mycoplasma genitalium
  • ﻿﻿Trichomonas vaginalis
  • ﻿﻿Herpes simplex virus (rare)
  • ﻿﻿Adenovirus
  • ﻿﻿Haemophilus vaginalis
  • ﻿﻿Mycoplasma genitalium

questions.text: A female patient presents to you with a unilateral headache. It is associated with nausea, photophobia, and phonophobia. What is the best drug for acute management? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Sumatriptan

 

The patient's symptoms are characteristic of a migraine, which is often associated with unilateral headache, nausea, photophobia (sensitivity to light), and phonophobia (sensitivity to sound).

 

Sumatriptan: This medication is a serotonin receptor agonist (triptan) used for the acute treatment of migraine attacks. It works by stimulating serotonin (5-HT) receptors in the brain, leading to vasoconstriction of dilated blood vessels and relief from migraine symptoms.

 

The best drug for acute management of a migraine attack in this scenario is Sumatriptan.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Flunarizine: This is a calcium channel blocker used for the prophylactic treatment of migraine, not for acute management.

 

Option C. Propranolol: This beta-blocker is also used for migraine prophylaxis, not for acute attacks.

 

Option D. Topiramate: Used for preventing migraine, not for treating an acute attack.

 

Educaitonal Objective:

 

Sumatriptan is the best medication for the acute management of migraine, characterized by unilateral headache, nausea, photophobia, and phonophobia.

questions.text: Identify the condition given in the image:  (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Acanthosis nigricans

 

  • Acanthosis nigricans is the illness depicted in the image.
  • It is characterized by thickened, gray-brown velvety plaques seen in flexural areas such as the back of the neck, axillae, inframammary creases, waist, and groin.
  • The release of epidermal growth factors in the affected area is the causal mechanism.
  • Acanthosis Nigricans may be benign or linked to a malignancy.

 

 

Acanthosis nigricans can also be seen in the following:

 

  • Multiple seborrhoeic keratoses
  • Drugs like nicotinic acid (Use for hyperlipidaemia treatment)
    • Other conditions associated with metabolic syndrome include polycystic ovarian syndrome, sleep apnea & non-alcoholic fatty liver disease.
    • The condition is managed by dietary & lifestyle modifications.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pityriasis rotunda

 

  • Description: This is a rare skin condition characterized by large, round patches of dry, scaly skin as shown in the image below.

 

 

Option B. Melasma

 

  • Description: Melasma is characterized by brown to gray-brown patches, mainly on the face (cheeks, bridge of the nose, forehead, chin, and above the upper lip). It's often called the "mask of pregnancy."

 

Option C. Dermatomyositis

 

  • Description: An inflammatory muscle disease, dermatomyositis presents with skin rash and muscle weakness. The rash is often reddish or purple, seen on the eyelids, knuckles, elbows, knees, and sometimes the chest and back.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Acanthosis nigricans is marked by a velvety darkening of the skin in body folds.
  • There's a notable link between obesity, acanthosis nigricans, and metabolic syndrome, with the latter condition often being a visible indicator of insulin resistance.
  • Recognizing acanthosis nigricans is vital as it can be a marker of underlying systemic issues that may require comprehensive medical evaluation.

 

References: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology 9th edition Chapter 147, Page nos 147.14-147.15

Williams Gynecology 3rd edition Page no 391

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman in her second pregnancy is diagnosed with deep vein thrombosis (DVT) at 30 weeks gestation. What is the drug of choice for her treatment? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) LMWH (Low Molecular Weight Heparin)

 

Low Molecular Weight Heparin (LMWH). LMWH is the preferred treatment for deep vein thrombosis (DVT) during pregnancy due to its safety profile and ease of monitoring. LMWH does not cross the placenta, making it safer for the fetus compared to other anticoagulants. Additionally, LMWH requires less frequent monitoring compared to unfractionated heparin, making it more convenient for both patients and healthcare providers during pregnancy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Warfarin: Warfarin is contraindicated in pregnancy because it crosses the placenta and can lead to fetal complications, including congenital malformations and bleeding. Warfarin is generally reserved for patients with specific conditions such as mechanical heart valves who were already on the drug before pregnancy, under careful supervision.

 

Option C. Fondaparinux: While Fondaparinux is an anticoagulant, it is not the first-line choice for DVT in pregnancy. It is generally considered when LMWH is contraindicated, such as in cases of heparin-induced thrombocytopenia.

 

Option D. Apixaban: Apixaban, a direct oral anticoagulant (DOAC), is not recommended in pregnancy due to insufficient safety data. DOACs are generally avoided during pregnancy because they can cross the placenta and pose risks to the fetus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In pregnancy, the drug of choice for treating DVT is Low Molecular Weight Heparin (LMWH) due to its safety and ease of monitoring compared to other anticoagulants

questions.text: A 27-year-old male came with complaints of asymptomatic generalized papulosquamous rash on trunk, moist flat grey perianal lesions and hair loss as given below. What is the most likely causative organism? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Treponema pallidum

 

The patient presents with several key clinical features: asymptomatic generalized papulosquamous rash on the trunk, moist flat grey perianal lesions (condyloma lata), and patchy hair loss. The patchy hair loss, described as "moth-eaten alopecia," is a characteristic feature of secondary syphilis. These signs are strongly indicative of an infection caused by Treponema pallidum, the bacterium responsible for syphilis. The presence of condyloma lata and the specific type of alopecia observed are classical clues pointing towards this diagnosis.

 

DD of Patchy Alopecia – Alopecia areata, Tinea capitis, Trichotillomania, and Secondary Syphilis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Malassezia furfur: This organism is associated with conditions like pityriasis versicolor and seborrheic dermatitis, neither of which typically present with the described combination of symptoms, particularly the moth-eaten alopecia and condyloma lata.

 

Option C. Staphylococcus aureus: While Staphylococcus aureus can cause skin infections and folliculitis, it does not typically cause the type of patchy alopecia or the other systemic symptoms described in this case.

 

Option D. Microsporum canis: This is a dermatophyte that causes tinea capitis, which can lead to patchy hair loss. However, tinea capitis would be associated with scaly patches and other signs of fungal infection rather than the systemic features like condyloma lata seen here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The "moth-eaten alopecia" is a key diagnostic feature of secondary syphilis, and Treponema pallidum is the causative organism.

questions.text:
Arrange the steps of the Demographic cycle in the correct chronological sequence: [NEET PG 2024]

 

  1. Low stationary
  2. High stationary
  3. Declining
  4. Early expanding
  5. Late expanding
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) 2 4 5 1 3

 

The Demographic Transition Model describes the stages a country goes through as it transitions from high birth and death rates to low birth and death rates. The stages of the demographic cycle in correct chronological order are:

 

2. High Stationary : This is the first stage characterized by high birth and high death rates, leading to a stable population. It reflects pre-industrial societies with limited medical care and poor living conditions.

 

4. Early Expanding: In this stage, death rates start to decline due to improvements in healthcare, sanitation, and nutrition, while birth rates remain high, resulting in rapid population growth.

 

5. Late Expanding : Birth rates begin to fall as societies become more urbanized and access to contraception improves, but the population continues to grow, albeit at a slower rate.

 

1. Low Stationary : Both birth and death rates are low, stabilizing the population size. This stage reflects advanced economies with high living standards and access to family planning.

 

3. Declining : In the final stage, the birth rate falls below the death rate, leading to a declining population. This stage is seen in highly developed countries with aging populations and very low fertility rates.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct sequence of the demographic cycle stages is: High Stationary, Early Expanding, Late Expanding, Low Stationary, and Declining.

questions.text: A child presents with generalized edema and was found to have hypercholesterolemia. Urinalysis shows protein 3+ and fat bodies. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Nephrotic syndrome

 

The clinical presentation of a child with generalized edema, hyperlipidemia, massive proteinuria, and fat bodies is highly suggestive of nephrotic syndrome, which is a glomerular disease characterized by heavy proteinuria. The diagnosis of nephrotic syndrome is based on the triad of hypoalbuminemia (≤2.5 g/dL), edema, and hyperlipidemia (cholesterol >200 mg/dL) in addition to proteinuria >3.5 g/24 hr or a urine protein:creatinine ratio >2.

 

Causes of Nephrotic Syndrome:

 

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Nephritic syndrome: Nephritic syndrome classically presents with tea- or cola-colored urine (hematuria), edema, hypertension, and oliguria.

 

Conditions which present as glomerulonephritis:

 

  • Postinfectious glomerulonephritis
  • IgA nephropathy (Option D)
  • Membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis
  • Henoch-Schönlein purpura (HSP) nephritis

 

Option C. Goodpasture syndrome: Goodpasture syndrome also referred to as anti-glomerular basement membrane (anti-GBM) disease, is an autoimmune disease that affects both the kidneys and lungs by the formation of autoantibodies that attack their basement membranes. Plasmapheresis is recommended in patients with pauci-immune crescentic GN and Goodpasture syndrome.

 

Option D. IgA nephropathy: IgA nephropathy, also known as Berger's disease, is a kidney disorder that occurs when immunoglobulin A (IgA), a protein that helps the body fight infections, settles in the kidneys. This can cause inflammation that, over time, can affect the kidneys' ability to filter waste from the blood. IgA nephropathy is one of the most common glomerulonephritis, a type of kidney disease that affects the glomeruli, the tiny filters within the kidneys that filter waste and excess fluids from the blood.

 

Some common features of IgA nephropathy include:

 

  1. Hematuria: The most common symptom is the presence of blood in the urine (hematuria), which can make the urine appear pink or cola-colored.
  2. Proteinuria: Protein in the urine (proteinuria) may also occur but is typically less significant than in other kidney diseases.
  3. High Blood Pressure: Some individuals may develop high blood pressure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nephrotic syndrome is characterized by generalized edema, hyperlipidemia, massive proteinuria, and fat bodies in urinalysis

questions.text: Alpha 1-antitrypsin is the major inhibitor of the enzyme: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Elastase

 

Alpha 1-antitrypsin is the major inhibitor of the enzyme neutrophil elastase.

 

On serum electrophoresis, alpha-1-antitrypsin (-1-AT), also known as alpha 1-protease inhibitor, is a glycoprotein that typically makes up the alpha1-globulin fraction of the plasma proteins.

 

It is typically produced in the liver and found in macrophages, circulating blood, and tissue fluids.

 

The name "Alpha1-protease inhibitor" comes from the fact that alpha1AT's primary role in the body is to inhibit proteases. The proteases, particularly the elastases, come from neutrophils.

 

The anti-elastase activity of alpha1-AT prevents neutrophil elastase from digesting lung parenchyma, despite its ability to do so.

 

In the proteinase inhibitor (Pi) locus on chromosome 14, co-dominantly expressed genes that code for 1-antitrypsin are located. The Pi locus has a wide variety of alleles and is highly polymorphic.

 

Those who have the alpha1-AT deficit develop panacinar pulmonary emphysema.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Catalase: Not primarily inhibited by A1AT; it is an antioxidant enzyme.

 

Option B. Collagenase: Also not a primary target of A1AT; these enzymes break down collagen in connective tissue.

 

Option D. Phospholipase: Not inhibited by A1AT; involved in the hydrolysis of phospholipids.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Alpha 1-antitrypsin's critical role is to inhibit neutrophil elastase, thus protecting connective tissue from inflammatory damage, particularly in the lungs and liver.

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient with a history of chronic alcohol use presents with complaints of confusion and ataxia. Upon examination, nystagmus and sixth nerve palsy were observed. What is the likely diagnosis?  (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Wernicke's Encephalopathy

 

The presentation of a 40-year-old patient with a history of chronic alcohol use, who is experiencing confusion, ataxia, nystagmus, and sixth nerve palsy, is highly suggestive of Wernicke's Encephalopathy. This is caused by thiamine (vitamin B1) deficiency, commonly seen in individuals with chronic alcohol use. Wernicke's Encephalopathy is characterized by the classic triad of confusion, oculomotor dysfunction (such as nystagmus and cranial nerve palsies), and ataxia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Korsakoff Syndrome: This is a chronic neuropsychiatric syndrome that often follows Wernicke's Encephalopathy. It is characterized by severe memory impairment, confabulation, and behavioral changes but lacks the acute neurological symptoms such as nystagmus and ataxia seen in Wernicke's Encephalopathy.

 

Option C. Delirium Tremens: This is a severe form of alcohol withdrawal characterized by delirium, tremors, agitation, hallucinations, and autonomic instability. While confusion is common, the specific neurological findings of nystagmus and sixth nerve palsy are more indicative of Wernicke's Encephalopathy.

 

Option D. De Clerambault Syndrome: Also known as erotomania, this is a delusional disorder characterized by the belief that another person is in love with the individual. It is unrelated to the symptoms presented in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Wernicke’s encephalopathy is caused by thiamine (vitamin B1) deficiency, which is common in individuals with chronic alcohol use due to poor nutritional intake and absorption. Treatment include high dose of parenteral thiamine. Ophthalmoplegia responds first to the treatment, ataxia doesnt improve completely in almost 50% of cases.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 277.

questions.text: Implantation of the embryo takes place how many days after fertilization? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 8


Implantation of the embryo typically starts around 5 to 6 days after fertilization and is usually completed by 8 to 9 days. After fertilization, the embryo undergoes several stages of development, including cleavage and blastocyst formation. The blastocyst travels down the fallopian tube and reaches the uterus by around day 5. It then begins to attach to and invade the uterine lining, completing the implantation process by around day 8. Therefore, 8 days is the most accurate answer representing the completion of the implantation process.

 

 

Educational Objective:


Implantation of the embryo begins around day 5 to 6 and is completed by day 8 to 9 after fertilization.

questions.text: A patient presents to the OPD with the lesion shown in the image. He had a traumatic injury to the chest one year ago. What is the most likely diagnosis?   (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Keloid

 

  • The image shows scar tissue is of a keloid.

 

Here is a comparison between Keloid and Hypertrophic scars:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hemangioma: A hemangioma is a vascular tumor that arises from the vascular endothelium.

 

 

Option B.Hypertrophic scar: Hypertrophic scar is limited to margins.

 

 

Option D. Neurofibroma: Neurofibromas are benign tumors arising from Schwann cells. Skin manifestations appear in early life, with the development of more than five smooth surfaced café-au-lait spots, subcutaneous neurofibromata, armpit or groin freckling and Lisch nodules.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Keloids are raised scars that extend beyond the original wound margin, are progressive, and do not regress on their own.
  •  They are most commonly seen in individuals with darker skin and may have a genetic predisposition.
  •  Treatment involves silicon sheets, intralesional steroids, laser ablation, and sometimes surgical excision with radiotherapy.

questions.text: Collapse in a patient during labor/ delivery followed by bleeding and DIC in the absence of coexisting conditions is most likely due to? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Amniotic fluid embolism

 

  • The given clinical scenario with a diagnosis of disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) points to amniotic fluid embolism as the most likely etiology.
  • Amniotic fluid embolism presents as 
    • hemodynamic and respiratory compromise, along with DIC.
    • Usually, it presents during the late stages of labor or immediate postpartum.
    • Gasping for air, seizures, and cardiorespiratory arrest are other features.

 

Diagnostic criteria for amniotic fluid embolism include:

 

  • Sudden onset cardiorespiratory arrest, or both hypotension and respiratory compromise
  • Overt DIC
  • Onset during labor or within 30 minutes of delivery of the placenta
  • No fever ≥38°C

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Postpartum haemorrhage: This will present as vaginal bleeding followed by collapse/ DIC

 

Option C. Eclampsia: This will present as seizures

 

Option D. Peripartum cardiomyopathy: This will present as cardiac failure following delivery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Collapse in a patient during labor/ delivery followed by bleeding and DIC in the absence of coexisting conditions is most likely due to amniotic fluid embolism.

questions.text: Identify the contraceptive shown in the given image: (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Female condom

 

Explanation:

 

  • The image is of a female condom. 
  • It is made of aa synthetic nitrile sheath with one flexible polyurethane ring at each end
  • One ring is open – lies outside the vagina.
  • The closed ring is fitted under the symphysis like a diaphragm
  • Male condoms should not be used simultaneously due to friction leading to slippage of condom or tearing
  • Also offers protection against STDs

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Male Condom:

 

 

Option C. Cervical diaphragm:

 

 

Option D. Cervical Cap:

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The female condom is a synthetic nitrile sheath with one flexible polyurethane ring at each end, providing contraceptive protection and protection against STDs.

 

Ref: Page n 612, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics, 8th edition

questions.text: A 3-year-old girl was brought by her mother with complaints of enlarged clitoris. Karyotype revealed 46XX. What is the likely cause? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 21 hydroxylase deficiency

 

The clinical scenario describes a 3-year-old girl with ambiguous genitalia, specifically an enlarged clitoris, and a karyotype of 46XX. This presentation is indicative of Congenital Adrenal Hyperplasia (CAH), which is most commonly caused by 21-hydroxylase deficiency.

 

21-hydroxylase deficiency is the most common form of CAH and accounts for more than 95% of cases. This enzyme deficiency leads to impaired cortisol production, which results in an increased production of androgens. The excess androgens cause virilization, leading to ambiguous genitalia in genotypically female infants.

 

Key Points:

 

  • Ambiguous genitalia: This includes an enlarged clitoris, which is often a sign of virilization due to increased androgens.
  • Karyotype 46XX: Confirms the genetic female status.
  • Increased serum androgens: Result from the enzyme deficiency and lead to masculinization of the external genitalia.

 

Clinical scenario: Ambiguous genitalia in a newborn female

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. 11 hydroxylase deficiency: This can also lead to CAH but is less common and typically presents with hypertension due to the accumulation of 11-deoxycorticosterone, which has mineralocorticoid activity.

 

Option C. 3 beta dehydrogenase deficiency: This is a rarer form of CAH and typically presents with both glucocorticoid and mineralocorticoid deficiencies along with ambiguous genitalia in both sexes.

 

Option D. 2, 3 lyase deficiency: This is not a commonly recognized cause of CAH. The primary enzyme deficiencies leading to CAH are 21-hydroxylase, 11-hydroxylase, and 17-hydroxylase deficiencies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most common cause of ambiguous genitalia in a newborn female (46XX) is 21-hydroxylase deficiency, a form of congenital adrenal hyperplasia.

choices.text: ﻿﻿﻿Soft exudate, Central retinal vein occlusion

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient with progressive painless loss of vision presents to the ophthalmology OPD. Fundus picture of the patient is given below. What could be the probable finding and the cause of it? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Hard exudate, Diabetes mellitus

 

The given image shows small, discrete yellowish, waxy areas with discrete margins that are suggestive of hard exudates, seen in diabetic macular edema.

 

 

COTTON WOOL SPOT vs HARD EXUDATE

 

 

Diabetic retinopathy

 

 

Hypertensive retinopathy

 

 

Central retinal vein occlusion (CRVO) – Fundoscopy reveals massive engorgement, congestion, and tortuosity of retinal veins. Ischemic CRVO has massive retinal hemorrhages giving a splashed tomato appearance involving the whole fundus.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Soft exudate, Hypertension: Soft exudates, also known as cotton wool spots, are whitish fluffy spots with indistinct margins.

 

They occur around infarcted areas and result from swelling of nerve fiber layer axons.

 

Associated with hypertensive retinopathy, toxaemic retinopathy of pregnancy, diabetic retinopathy, anemias, and collagen disorders like discoid lupus erythematosus, polyarteritis nodosa, and scleroderma.

 

Option C. Flame-shaped hemorrhages, Hypertension: Flame-shaped hemorrhages are superficial retinal hemorrhages that occur due to disruption of the capillaries in the retinal nerve fiber layer.

 

They are seen in diabetic retinopathy, non-ischemic central retinal vein occlusion, traumatic retinopathy, Eale's disease, hypertensive retinopathy, and anemic retinopathy.

 

Option D. Soft exudate, Central retinal vein occlusion: Central retinal vein occlusion (CRVO) is characterized by massive engorgement, congestion, and tortuosity of retinal veins.

 

Ischemic CRVO has massive retinal hemorrhages giving a splashed tomato appearance involving the whole fundus.

 

Soft exudates can be seen in CRVO but are not the primary finding.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hard exudates are characteristic findings in diabetic retinopathy, indicating chronic localized edema and composed of leaked lipoproteins and lipid-filled macrophages. They present as small, discrete yellowish, waxy areas with distinct margins in the retina.

questions.text: What constitutes the primary administrative unit in India? [NEET PG 2019]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) District

 

  • The principal unit of administration in India is the district, which is administered by a Collector.
  • The district is the basic unit of administration in India and is responsible for implementing various government schemes and programs at the grassroots level. It is headed by a District Collector or Deputy Commissioner, who is responsible for maintaining law and order, revenue administration, and developmental activities in the district.
  • Under districts are the sub-divisions, tehsils or talukas, municipalities or corporations, villages, panchayats, etc.
  • According to 2023 data, there are 766 districts in India

 

Educational Objective:

 

The district serves as the principal administrative unit in India, playing a vital role in governance and implementation of government policies at the grassroots level.

questions.text: Identify the condition that presents with painful vesicles as shown below: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Herpes simplex virus

 

The condition shown in the image is characterized by painful vesicles, which is a hallmark of herpes simplex virus (HSV) infection. HSV causes fluid-filled vesicles that are often painful, and these lesions can occur on the skin or mucous membranes, including genital areas. The vesicles eventually rupture, forming shallow, painful ulcers. HSV can present as recurrent outbreaks, especially during periods of stress or weakened immune function.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Candidiasis: Candidiasis typically presents with white, curd-like discharge and redness, particularly in mucous membranes like the mouth or vagina. It does not cause vesicles or painful ulcers.

 

Option B. Syphilis: Syphilis typically presents with a painless chancre in the primary stage, followed by a rash and other systemic symptoms in later stages. Vesicles are not a feature of syphilis.

 

Option C. Chancroid: Chancroid, caused by Haemophilus ducreyi, presents with painful genital ulcers but does not form fluid-filled vesicles. The ulcers are more ragged and deeper compared to those seen in HSV infections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Painful vesicles are characteristic of herpes simplex virus infection. Remember the association of HSV with painful, fluid-filled vesicles, especially in genital or mucosal areas.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male, presents to the emergency department with complaints of severe pain, swelling and redness in scrotal area. He undergoes a surgical procedure for the same. Based on the image below, what is the likely diagnosis?(NEET  PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Fournier’s gangrene

 

  • The given postoperative image is suggestive of the "shameful exposure of testes" done after debridement for Fournier’s gangrene.
  • Fournier's gangrene is a rare but serious bacterial infection of the scrotum and perineum area leading to gangrene.
  • It is characterized by rapid and progressive necrosis (death) of the tissue in the genital and perineal regions and can spread to the surrounding tissue and organs.
  • Symptoms of Fournier's gangrene may include severe pain, swelling, redness, and foul-smelling discharge from the affected area.
  • Early diagnosis and treatment with antibiotics and surgical debridement (removal of dead tissue) are critical in managing Fournier's gangrene, as the condition can be life-threatening if left untreated.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Torsion of testis: Testicular torsion is a medical emergency that occurs when the spermatic cord, which provides blood flow to the testicle, rotates and becomes twisted. This cuts off the blood flow and can lead to the death of the testicle if not treated promptly. Symptoms typically include sudden and severe pain in one testicle, swelling, redness, and often nausea and vomiting. The affected testicle may lie horizontally and be high-riding. Testicular torsion requires immediate surgical intervention to untwist the spermatic cord and save the testicle.

 

Option B. Acute epididymo-orchitis: Epididymo-orchitis is the inflammation of the epididymis and/or testicle. It is usually caused by an infection, which can be either bacterial or viral. Symptoms include pain, redness, and swelling in the scrotal area, often accompanied by fever. The affected area would be tender on palpation. Treatment typically involves antibiotics and pain relief.

 

Option C. Scrotal carcinoma: Scrotal carcinoma would present as a growth or ulcerative lesion on the skin of the scrotum. It wouldn't typically cause the acute, severe symptoms described in the scenario. However, it is essential to consider malignancy in long-standing, non-healing ulcers or growths in the scrotal area.

 

  • Given the severe pain, swelling, redness, and the nature of the postoperative image showing debridement, Fournier's gangrene (Option D) is the most likely diagnosis for this patient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Fournier's gangrene is a life-threatening condition requiring urgent surgical intervention and aggressive antibiotic therapy.
  • Early recognition and prompt treatment are crucial to improve patient outcomes.

questions.text: Roth spots are seen in:
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Acute leukemia

 

  • Roth's spots are retinal hemorrhages with white or pale centers, named after Moritz Roth.
  • Roth spots are classically described in and are considered as pathognomonic of Subacute Bacterial Endocarditis with the yellowish-white centre consisting of a focus of embolic infection.
  • They are commonly seen in other conditions as well.
  • In leukaemia, the white center typically represents fibrin-platelet plugs.
  • Roth's spots are composed of coagulated fibrin, including platelets, focal ischemia, inflammatory infiltrate, infectious organisms, or neoplastic cells.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Uveal melanoma: A primary cancer of the eye involving the iris, ciliary body, or choroid, not typically associated with Roth spots.

 

Option C. Uveal lymphoma: A rare type of eye cancer affecting the uvea, not commonly associated with Roth spots.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Roth's spots may be seen in -

 

1. Leukemia

2. Diabetes

3. Subacute bacterial endocarditis

4. Hypertensive retinopathy

5. HIV retinopathy

6. Systemic lupus erythematosus

7. Anemia

8. Pre-eclampsia

9. Anoxi

questions.text: A patient with reduced hemoglobin and gum bleeding presented to you. He has thrombocytopenia (platelet count 25,000/µl) elevated PT, and aPTT. Which of the following can the probable cause of his finding? (NEETPG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) AML t (15;17)

 

The clinical presentation of reduced hemoglobin, gum bleeding, thrombocytopenia, and elevated PT and aPTT is suggestive of disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC). Acute promyelocytic leukemia (APL), which is associated with the t(15;17) translocation, is a subtype of acute myeloid leukemia (AML) that commonly presents with DIC.

 

Acute Promyelocytic Leukemia (APL):

 

  • Genetics: APL is characterized by the t(15;17) translocation, which results in the PML-RARA fusion gene. This translocation disrupts the retinoic acid receptor alpha (RARA) gene, leading to a block in myeloid differentiation at the promyelocyte stage.
  • Clinical Features: Patients often present with symptoms of bleeding (e.g., gum bleeding, bruising) due to DIC, which is a common complication of APL.
  • Laboratory Findings: Thrombocytopenia, elevated PT, and aPTT are consistent with DIC. The peripheral smear may show promyelocytes with Auer rods.
  • Management: APL is treated with all-trans retinoic acid (ATRA), which induces differentiation of the malignant promyelocytes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. AML t(8;21): Associated with AML with maturation, typically presenting with myeloblasts and not commonly associated with DIC.

 

Option C. AML t(16;16): Associated with AML with abnormal eosinophils, also not commonly associated with DIC.

 

Option D. AML with NPM1: NPM1 mutations are common in AML but do not specifically correlate with DIC or the presentation described.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Acute promyelocytic leukemia (APL) associated with t(15;17) translocation commonly presents with DIC, characterized by thrombocytopenia and elevated coagulation times (PT and aPTT). DIC is due to release of procoagulant substances from the abnormal promyelocytes. Immediate identification and treatment with ATRA are crucial to manage this condition effectively.

questions.text: True regarding mitochondrial genome?(NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Maternal inheritance

 

  • The mitochondrial genome is inherited maternally, which means it is passed down from the mother to her offspring. This is because mitochondria are typically inherited from the cytoplasm of the egg cell. Sperm contributes very little, if any, mitochondria to the zygote, and paternal mitochondria are usually degraded after fertilization.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Low Rate of Mutation: False Mitochondrial DNA is known to have a relatively high mutation rate compared to nuclear DNA. This higher mutation rate is partly due to the lack of protective histones and efficient DNA repair mechanisms in mitochondria. As a result, mutations in mitochondrial DNA can accumulate over time.

 

Option C. Single-stranded DNA: False Mitochondrial DNA is double-stranded, just like nuclear DNA. It forms a circular double-stranded DNA molecule. This structure is distinct from the single-stranded DNA found in some viruses and certain cellular processes.

 

Option D. Paternal Inheritance: False Mitochondrial DNA is not inherited from the father; it is exclusively maternally inherited. Paternal mitochondria are generally not passed on to the offspring during fertilization.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mitochondrial DNA and RNA:

 

  1. There is a dichotomy on the mitochondrial metabolism. Some of the mitochondrial protein synthesis is under the control of mitochondrial DNA; but important proteins of the outer membrane of the mitochondria are synthesized under the influence of nuclear DNA.
  2. The mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA) is circular, has about 16,500 nucleotides. The mtDNA has information for synthesis of 2 ribosomal RNAs, 22 tRNAs and 13 proteins. All of them are components of electron transport chain. It has 37 genes that encode 13 protein subunits of the respiratory chain (total of 67 i.e., about 20%). However, most of mitochondrial proteins are encoded by nuclear DNA and synthesized in the cytoplasm.
  3. Maternal inheritance: Since, the mitochondria are inherited cytoplasmically, the mtDNA is inherited from the mother. Mother transmits mtDNA through oocyte.
  4. There are hundreds of copies of mtDNA in each cell (nuclear DNA has only 2 copies).
  5. Heteroplasmy is defined as the presence of normal and mutant mtDNA in different proportions in different cells. During cell division, mtDNA replicates and they segregate to the daughter cells. If a mutation occurs in mtDNA, the daughter cells may inherit the mutant or normal mtDNA.
  6. High mutation rate: 5-10 times that of nuclear DNA
  7. Age-related accumulation of mutations in mtDNA may be responsible for age-related decrease in cellular OXPHOS function, and progression of other degenerative diseases.
  8. Defects in mitochondrial genome will lead to mitochondrial myopathies.

questions.text: Which of the following is seen in low insulin: glucagon ratio?(NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Activation of hormone-sensitive lipase

 

In a fasting state, insulin decreases and glucagon increases, hence there is Low insulin: glucagon ratio. Since insulin has an inhibitory effect on hormone-sensitive lipase, low insulin: glucagon ratio results in the activation of hormone-sensitive lipase.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Activation of lipoprotein lipase (LPL) is promoted by insulin, but here it is low. Lipoprotein lipase enzyme breaks triglycerides (TGs) of Lipoproteins (Chylomicrons and VLDL) to give 3 fatty acids and glycerol.

 

Option B. Activation of glycogen synthase is promoted by insulin (fed state). In low insulin: glucagon ratio, glycogen synthase activity will be reduced, leading to decreased glycogenesis.

 

Option C. Activation of phosphoructokinase-1 (PFK1) is promoted by insulin (fed state). PFK1 is a rate-regulating enzyme in glycolysis.

 

Educational objective:

 

Hormone-sensitive lipase is present inside the cells of adipose tissues. Stored triglycerides in adipose tissues are broken by HSL into 3 fatty acids and glycerol. 3 fatty acids go in blood and then are taken by liver where β- Oxidation of fatty acids (catabolic) occurs to give energy in Liver.

 

In diabetic patients, low insulin level which causes an increase in HSL activity, promoting the breakdown of lipids and the release of FFAs from adipose tissue. HSL activity is accelerated by hormones like epinephrine, norepinephrine, glucagon, ACTH, TSH, GH, ADH, and melanocyte-stimulating hormones (MSH).

questions.text: In which part of the fallopian tube does fertilization occur? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ampulla

 

Explanation:

 

 

Ampulla:

 

  • The ampulla is the widest section of the fallopian tube and is the most common site for fertilization.
  • This region provides an optimal environment for the sperm to meet the ovum and for the subsequent fertilization process to occur.
  • The ampulla is also the most common site of ectopic pregnancy, where a fertilized egg implants and grows outside the main cavity of the uterus.

 

Structure of the Fallopian Tube:

 

The fallopian tube has four main parts:

 

  1. Infundibulum: The funnel-shaped opening near the ovary with finger-like projections called fimbriae.
  2. Ampulla: The widest and longest part where fertilization typically occurs.
  3. Isthmus: A narrow section adjacent to the uterus.
  4. Interstitial (or intramural): The part that traverses the uterine wall and opens into the uterine cavity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Isthmus: The isthmus is the narrow section of the fallopian tube close to the uterus. While it plays a role in the transport of the fertilized egg to the uterus, it is not the primary site for fertilization.

 

Option C. Interstitial: This portion of the fallopian tube traverses the uterine wall and opens into the uterine cavity. It is not typically where fertilization occurs.

 

Option D. Infundibular: The infundibulum is the funnel-shaped opening near the ovary, equipped with fimbriae to help capture the released ovum. Fertilization does not typically occur here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fertilization typically occurs in the ampulla of the fallopian tube, which is the widest and longest part of the tube.

 

Ref: Page no 23, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 8th edition

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presented to the emergency department with severe abdominal pain that had been ongoing for the past 24 hours. He reported that he had been consuming alcohol heavily for the past few weeks. The physical examination revealed tenderness in the upper abdomen with no visible signs of jaundice. Pancreatitis was suspected, and a CT scan was performed, which revealed lesions with fluid collected near the body of the pancreas. The patient was started on appropriate treatment, and blood tests were ordered to help diagnose the condition. Which enzyme is most likely to be elevated in this scenario? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Serum lipase

 

  • An alcoholic patient with acute pancreatitis is most likely to have elevated serum lipase levels.
  •  Clinical findings and elevated pancreatic enzymes in the plasma are used to diagnose acute pancreatitis.
  • Lipase is a more sensitive and specific marker of acute pancreatitis than amylase, which can be elevated in other conditions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Serum GGT : GGT (Gamma-glutamyltransferase) is an enzyme primarily found in the liver. It is an important marker for liver disease, especially conditions associated with bile duct obstruction. Elevated GGT would not specifically indicate pancreatitis.

 

Option B. CEA : CEA (Carcinoembryonic antigen) is a tumor marker, primarily used to monitor certain types of cancers, particularly colorectal cancer. It can be elevated in some pancreatic cancers as well, but it's not specifically used to diagnose or monitor acute pancreatitis.

 

Option D. Serum bilirubin: Bilirubin is a product of red blood cell breakdown and is processed by the liver. Elevated serum bilirubin levels can indicate liver disease or a blockage of the bile duct, which can be due to a stone, tumor, or other causes. In the context of pancreatitis, elevated bilirubin can be seen in biliary pancreatitis when a gallstone obstructs the common bile duct, but it's not a specific marker for pancreatitis itself.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Serum lipase is the most specific enzyme for diagnosing acute pancreatitis, especially in cases related to alcohol consumption.
  •  It rises within 12 to 24 hours of pancreatic injury and remains elevated for 7-14 days, making it a crucial diagnostic marker for this condition.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a part of revised trauma score (RTS)?(NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Pulse rate

 

Pulse rate is NOT a part of revised trauma score.

 

The Revised Trauma Score (RTS) is a scoring system used to evaluate the severity of traumatic injuries in patients.

 

It takes into account the Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS), systolic blood pressure, and respiratory rate to calculate a score that can predict the likelihood of survival.

 

The score range is 0-12.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Glasgow Coma Scale: The GCS is included in the RTS and evaluates the patient's level of consciousness based on eye, verbal, and motor responses.

 

Option B. Systolic Blood Pressure: SBP is included in the RTS and measures the pressure in the arteries when the heart beats.

 

Option D. Respiratory Rate: RR is included in the RTS and measures the number of breaths per minute.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Revised Trauma Score (RTS) includes the Glasgow Coma Scale, systolic blood pressure, and respiratory rate, but does not include pulse rate.

questions.text: A 39 year G2P1 presents at 18 weeks 5 days for her routine targeted fetal anomaly ultrasound. The fetal anatomy appears normal, but the cervical length is 15mm. Despite being counselled that there is no clear proven benefit for the same; the patient insisted on a cervical cerclage. Which of the following is a complete contra-indication to cerclage? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ruptured membranes

 

Explanation:

 

  • Ruptured Membranes:
    • Ruptured membranes are a complete contraindication to cerclage. When the membranes are ruptured, there is an increased risk of infection and complications, making the procedure unsafe.
    • Ruptured membranes are a complete contraindication to cerclage. When the membranes are ruptured, there is an increased risk of infection and complications, making the procedure unsafe.
    • Cerclage involves stitching the cervix closed to prevent premature birth, which is not advisable when the protective amniotic sac is compromised.

 

Absolute Contraindications to Cervical Cerclage

 

  • Active labor
  • Clinical signs of chorioamnionitis
  • Preterm premature rupture of membranes (PPROM)
  • Fetal demise (IUFD)
  • Major fetal anomalies incompatible with life
  • Significant vaginal bleeding due to placental abruption
  • ruptured membranes 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Positive fetal fibronectin test: A positive fetal fibronectin test indicates an increased risk of preterm labor but is not an absolute contraindication to cerclage. This test measures the presence of fetal fibronectin, a protein that acts as a "glue" during pregnancy, keeping the amniotic sac attached to the lining of the uterus.

 

Option B. Membranes bulging into the vagina: While bulging membranes present a high-risk situation, they are not an absolute contraindication to cerclage. In some cases, cerclage can still be performed with careful management.

 

Option D. Advanced maternal age: Advanced maternal age is not a contraindication to cerclage. While it may increase the overall risk profile of the pregnancy, it does not specifically contraindicate the procedure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ruptured membranes are a complete contraindication to cervical cerclage due to the increased risk of infection and complications.

 

Ref: Page 543, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: What is the first line of treatment of mastitis in a lactating mother? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Dicloxacillin

 

Explanation:

 

Beta-lactamase-resistant penicillins are recommended in the treatment of mastitis. These include cloxacillin, dicloxacillin, or flucloxacillin. Erythromycin is given to women who are penicillin-sensitive. Dicloxacillin is often the first choice due to its effectiveness against the common causative organism, Staphylococcus aureus.

 

Puerperal Mastitis:

 

  • Definition: Mastitis is an inflammatory condition of the breast that may occur in breastfeeding women during the puerperium.
  • Pathogenesis: Infants are inoculated by personnel carrying S. aureus and transmit the bacteria to the breastfeeding mother through the nasopharynx.
  • Risk Factors:
    • Maternal age > 30 years
    • Maternal fatigue and stress
    • Sores and cracked nipples
    • History of mastitis after a previous pregnancy
    • Breast engorgement, blocked lactiferous ducts, and milk stasis
  • Etiology:
    • Most cases of mastitis result from infection with S. aureus.
    • Other organisms include coagulase-negative staphylococci, β-hemolytic streptococci, Streptococcus faecalis, Escherichia coli, and other bacteria such as Enterobacter cloacae, Pseudomonas picetti, and Haemophilus influenzae.
  • Diagnosis:
    • Maternal fever (100.4°F or higher)
    • Chills, myalgia, malaise
    • Breast tenderness with associated erythema, usually unilateral
    • Segmental erythema on the breast, typically in the upper, outer quadrant, with variable degrees of induration
    • Palpable, fluctuant mass suggesting a breast abscess should prompt immediate breast ultrasound
    • Milk may be expressed for leukocyte and bacterial counts, though this is not recommended for diagnosing uncomplicated mastitis
  • Treatment:
    • Antibiotics: Dicloxacillin, amoxicillin, or nafcillin, or a first-generation cephalosporin
    • Penicillin Allergy: Erythromycin or vancomycin
    • Duration: Antibiotic therapy should be continued for 10 to 14 days to avoid resistant organisms
    • Breastfeeding: Women should continue breastfeeding, initiating feeds on the unaffected breast and changing the infant's position at different feeds to prevent the development of a breast abscess
    • Symptomatic Relief: Analgesics like ibuprofen or acetaminophen, increased fluid intake, adequate nutrition, cold or warm compresses, and breast support should be provided

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cefazolin: While cefazolin is a cephalosporin and can be effective, it is not the first-line treatment compared to dicloxacillin for mastitis.

 

Option C. Ceftriaxone: Ceftriaxone is typically used for more severe infections and is not the first-line treatment for mastitis.

 

Option D. Ampicillin: Ampicillin may be used but is not as effective as dicloxacillin for treating Staphylococcus aureus infections in mastitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dicloxacillin is the first-line treatment for mastitis in lactating mothers, especially effective against Staphylococcus aureus.

 

Ref: https://www.glowm.com/section-view/heading/Puerperal%20Mastitis/item/142

questions.text: An elderly gentleman has presented with symptoms of difficulty swallowing, regurgitation, bad breath, and cough. He also exhibits bilateral lung crepitations upon examination. Which of the following is the most probable diagnosis? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Zenker's Diverticulum

 

Explanation:

 

Zenker's diverticulum is a pulsion diverticulum where pharyngeal mucosa herniates through Killian's dehiscence (a weak area between two parts of the inferior constrictor muscle). This condition typically affects patients over 60 years of age, matching our elderly patient's demographic. The classic symptoms include dysphagia (difficulty swallowing), regurgitation of undigested food (especially at night when recumbent), halitosis (bad breath), and cough with aspiration pneumonia (explaining the bilateral lung crepitations).

 

Visual Support

 

Zenker's diverticulum occurs when herniation of pouch starts in the midline. It is at first behind the esophagus and then comes to lie on its left. The mouth of the sac is wider than the opening of esophagus, so food preferentially enters the sac.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Schatzki Ring: This is a narrow ring of tissue at the lower end of the esophagus and would not cause regurgitation of undigested food or aspiration pneumonia. It typically presents with intermittent dysphagia for solids only, not the constellation of symptoms described.

 

Option C. Corkscrew Esophagus: This is a motility disorder (diffuse esophageal spasm) characterized by non-peristaltic contractions. While it can cause dysphagia, it does not lead to regurgitation of undigested food, halitosis, or aspiration pneumonia as seen in this patient.

 

Option D. Plummer-Vinson Syndrome: This condition is characterized by hypochromic microcytic anemia, dysphagia, and esophageal webs. It typically affects women in their 40s and 50s, not elderly men. It is not associated with regurgitation, halitosis, or aspiration pneumonia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Zenker's diverticulum should be suspected in elderly patients presenting with dysphagia, regurgitation of undigested food, halitosis, and respiratory complications due to aspiration, as the pouch traps food that can later be regurgitated and aspirated.

questions.text: During a health education session, people cannot understand your few technical words during the chat, and it’s a miscommunication. This is which type of barrier? [NEET PG 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Semantic barrier


A semantic barrier, also known as a linguistic barrier, arises when there is a difference in language or when technical jargon and complex terms are used that the audience cannot understand. This leads to miscommunication because the message is not clearly conveyed. In the given scenario, the use of technical words during the health education session caused a communication breakdown because the audience did not understand those terms. This is a classic example of a semantic barrier.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cultural barrier: A cultural barrier occurs when differences in customs, beliefs, caste or religion prevent effective communication. This is not the case here as the issue was related to language and technical terms, not cultural differences.

 

Option B. Physiological barrier: Physiological barriers include physical issues like hearing difficulties or speech impairments that obstruct communication. These are not relevant to the scenario described, where language misunderstanding was the primary issue.

 

Option C. Psychological barrier: Psychological barriers stem from emotional disturbances, stress, or mental conditions that hinder effective communication. While these can affect communication, they are unrelated to the miscommunication caused by technical words in this example.

 

Educational Objective:


A semantic barrier occurs when the use of complex language, technical terms, or unfamiliar words leads to misunderstanding and miscommunication.

questions.text: A patient underwent a coronary bypass graft with the great saphenous vein. The patient now complains of paresthesia and sensory loss over the medial aspect of the leg and foot. Which of the following nerves is most likely to be involved?(NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Saphenous nerve

 

  • The patient's symptoms of paresthesia and sensory loss over the medial aspect of the leg and foot indicate possible damage to the saphenous nerve, which can occur during a venous cutdown procedure to access the great saphenous vein for coronary bypass graft.
  • The saphenous nerve is a major cutaneous branch of the femoral nerve and is the longest nerve in the body.
  • After arising from the posterior division of the femoral nerve, it enters and exits the adductor canal before piercing the fascia lata between the gracilis and sartorius muscles.
  • From there, it runs along the medial border of the tibia alongside the great saphenous vein and supplies sensation to the skin over the patella, knee, leg, and foot, up to the first metatarsophalangeal joint.
  • During a venous cutdown procedure, injury to the saphenous nerve is common due to its proximity to the great saphenous vein.
  • The resulting sensory loss typically affects the medial aspect of the knee, leg, and foot.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Superficial Peroneal Nerve: This nerve originates from the common peroneal nerve (a branch of the sciatic nerve). It runs in the lateral compartment of the leg.

 

  • Sensory Distribution: Supplies sensation to the dorsum (top) of the foot and a small area over the lateral aspect of the lower leg.
  • Clinical Manifestation of Injury: Loss of sensation in its sensory distribution and potential weakness in eversion of the foot.

 

Option C. Femoral Nerve: Arises from the lumbar plexus (L2-L4).

 

  • Motor Functions: It supplies the anterior compartment muscles of the thigh which are primarily responsible for hip flexion and knee extension.
  • Sensory Distribution: Over the anterior thigh and medial aspect of the leg (via the saphenous nerve, its branch).
  • Clinical Manifestation of Injury: Weakness in hip flexion and knee extension along with sensory loss over its distribution.

 

Option D. Sural Nerve: This nerve is formed by branches from both the tibial and common peroneal nerves. It runs along the posterior and then lateral side of the calf.

 

  • Sensory Distribution: Supplies the posterolateral aspect of the leg and the lateral side of the foot.
  • Clinical Manifestation of Injury: Loss of sensation in its sensory distribution.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Percentage of undernourished children under 5 years

questions.text: Which of these options is not part of the Global Hunger Index (GHI)? [NEET PG 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Infant mortality rate

 

  • Infant mortality rate is not a component of the global hunger index (GHI).
  • The three components of the GHI are - 
    • Inadequate food supply [PNU – Undernourished Population]
    • Child mortality (under the age of 5) [U5M – Under 5 Mortality]
