    • Malnutrition (wasting, stunting) [CUW – Child underweight]

 

The GHI is a tool used to measure and track hunger at global, regional, and national levels.

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Global Hunger Index (GHI) does not include the infant mortality rate. It focuses on inadequate food supply, child mortality under the age of five, and child undernutrition as its key components to assess hunger and malnutrition.

choices.text: Hymen does not rupture because opening is too small to allow penis to enter
The hymen does not rupture because Hymen is situated deep inside

questions.text: If a young female child is raped, the hymen is usually: (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Both a and b

 

Rape on Children:

 

In rape of a young female, the hymen is usually not ruptured because of two reasons:

 

  • Vaginal opening is very small, hence penetration very difficult. Usually, the penis is placed either within the vulva or between the thighs. And as such, only redness and tenderness of vulva may be caused.
  • Hymen is deeply situated, hence even if some penetration occurred, it is not ruptured.

 

Also, in a child, there may be no signs or very few signs of general violence since the child has no idea of the act and is also unable to offer resistance.

 

However, in rare cases of great violence, the penis may be forcibly introduced, causing rupture of the vaginal vault, Hymen and associated visceral injuries. In this case the injuries will be more severe than adults and such injuries might result in death.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of rape involving a young female, the hymen is usually not ruptured because the vaginal opening is very small, making penetration difficult, and the hymen is situated deeply. Additionally, children may not show signs of general violence due to their inability to resist, though severe injuries can occur in cases of great violence.

questions.text: The following parameter in ALL indicate a poor prognosis: (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Age > 10 years

 

Age >10 years indicates a poor prognosis in ALL.

 

Leukocyte count <50,000/mm, hyperdiploidy, trisomy of chromosomes 4, 10, 17 indicate a better prognosis.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

In Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia (ALL), prognostic factors such as age greater than 10 years, WBC count greater than 200,000/mm^3, male gender, presence of CNS involvement, and certain cytogenetic abnormalities such as t(9;22) or t(4;11) are associated with a poorer prognosis compared to their counterparts.

choices.text: Aspirin increases fever by inhibiting prostaglandin synthesis
PGI2 is responsible for resetting the temperature to a higher level
Fever occurs during inflammation due to release of histamine

questions.text: Which of the following is true about fever? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) IL-1 is an endogenous pyrogen

 

Fever is a common symptom of many illnesses, and it is an important defense mechanism of the body. It is often associated with infection, inflammation, and tissue damage. Pyrogens are substances that cause fever.

 

IL-1 (interleukin-1) is an endogenous pyrogen, meaning that it is a substance produced by the body that induces fever. It is produced by activated immune cells such as macrophages and monocytes in response to infection, inflammation, and tissue damage. IL-1 acts on the hypothalamus to increase the set point of the thermostat, leading to a higher body temperature.

 

  • Endogenous pyrogens, such as prostaglandins, IL-1, and TNF
  • Exogenous pyrogens, which are bacterial lipopolysaccharides. They cause endogenous pyrogens to be released from leukocytes (IL-1 and TNF)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aspirin and other nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs): Aspirin and other nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) actually reduce fever by inhibiting the synthesis of prostaglandins, which are involved in the process of fever. Prostaglandins are produced by cells in the hypothalamus in response to pyrogens (fever-inducing substances), and they increase the set point of the hypothalamic thermostat, leading to a higher body temperature. NSAIDs inhibit the enzyme cyclooxygenase (COX), which is required for the synthesis of prostaglandins, thereby reducing fever.

 

Option B. PGI2 (prostaglandin I2): PGI2 (prostaglandin I2) is not responsible for resetting the temperature to a higher level.

 

Option D. Histamine: Histamine is not directly involved in the process of fever, although it is involved in the process of inflammation. Histamine is a chemical mediator that is released by mast cells and other immune cells in response to injury or infection, and it causes dilation of blood vessels and increased permeability of capillaries. This leads to the characteristic redness, swelling, and heat that are associated with inflammation. However, histamine does not directly cause fever.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy presented with abdominal pain, vomiting, oliguria, and periorbital puffiness following chemotherapy. Investigations reveal hyperuricemia and hyperkalemia. What is the next best step in the management of this condition? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hydration

 

The clinical scenario and the laboratory investigations are suggestive of tumor lysis syndrome. Aggressive hydration is the next best step in the management of this condition.

 

  • Tumor lysis syndrome (TLS) can occur after chemotherapy due to release of intracellular components.
  • Increased uric acid levels cause hyperuricemia, while release of potassium and phosphate leads to hyperkalemia and hyperphosphatemia.
  • Hyperphosphatemia leads to reciprocal depression of serum calcium causing hypocalcemia.
  • TLS can result in renal failure due to deposition of uric acid crystals, calcium phosphate, and hyperphosphatemia.
  • Signs and symptoms of TLS include abdominal pain, dysuria, oliguria, flank pain, anorexia, vomiting, cramps, seizures, altered mental status, tetany, weakness, and paralysis.
  • The Cairo-Bishop criteria are used to assess the severity of TLS.
  • Management of TLS includes measuring electrolytes and aggressive hydration before starting therapy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Probenecid: Probenecid inhibits the organic anion transporter in the nephron, thereby inhibiting the reabsorption of uric acid. However, it is contraindicated in TLS as it increases the risk of uric acid stones due to increased uric acid levels.

 

Option C. Allopurinol: Allopurinol and febuxostat are xanthine oxidase inhibitors that decrease uric acid synthesis and treat hyperuricemia. While they are useful in managing hyperuricemia, aggressive hydration is the first-line treatment in TLS to prevent renal failure.

 

Option D. Rasburicase: Rasburicase is an enzyme that degrades uric acid and is preferred in TLS over allopurinol for rapidly reducing uric acid levels. However, initial aggressive hydration is crucial before administering rasburicase.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Aggressive hydration is the first-line management for tumor lysis syndrome (TLS) to prevent renal failure and facilitate the excretion of released intracellular components.

questions.text: Which of the following is not seen in MEN 2B syndrome? (Neet pg 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Parathyroid adenoma

 

Parathyroid adenomas are not seen in MEN 2B. Parathyroid adenomas are typically associated with MEN 1 and MEN 2A syndromes, where hyperparathyroidism is a common feature due to the involvement of the parathyroid glands.

 

Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia type 2B (MEN 2B) is a genetic syndrome characterized by specific clinical features. It is also known as the "Triple M syndrome" because it typically presents with the following:

 

  • Mucosal Neuromas: These are benign growths on the mucous membranes and are a hallmark of MEN 2B.
  • Marfanoid Habitus: This refers to a body habitus resembling Marfan syndrome, with features like long limbs, a tall, slender build, and hyperflexible joints.
  • Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma (MTC): This is a type of thyroid cancer commonly associated with MEN 2B.

 

Other features that can be seen in MEN 2B include pheochromocytomas (tumors of the adrenal glands) and ganglioneuromas (tumors of the nerve cells).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Megacolon: Megacolon can be associated with MEN 2B due to the presence of ganglioneuromatosis affecting the gastrointestinal tract.

 

Option C. Mucosal Neuroma: As mentioned, mucosal neuromas are a classic feature of MEN 2B and one of the reasons it is called "triple M syndrome."

 

Option D. Marfanoid Habitus: This characteristic physical appearance is commonly seen in MEN 2B patients.

 

Educational Objective:

 

MEN 2B syndrome, also known as "triple M syndrome," is characterized by mucosal neuromas, marfanoid habitus, and medullary thyroid carcinoma, but does not involve parathyroid adenomas.

questions.text: Identify the finding shown in the image below: (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Herpes labialis

 

Explanation:

 

  • Herpes labialis, also known as a cold sore, is characterized by clusters of numerous grouped vesicles around the lips.
  • Recurrent herpetic lesions are very common & are vesicular and ulcerative and tend to occur in the same region.
  • Herpes simplex virus type 1 (HSV-1) commonly and type 2 (HSV-2) rarely are responsible for its occurrence

 

Treatment: Foscarnet or cidofovir if acyclovir resistance develops in a patient with recurrent Herpes labialis. They act on viral DNA polymerases thus blocking DNA replication.

  • Oral acyclovir 200 mg and 5% topical acyclovir.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Herpangina or vesicular pharyngitis:

 

  • It is characterized by the presence of ulcerating small vesicles on the oral fauces and the posterior pharyngeal wall as seen in the below image.

 

 

  • Causative agent: Coxsackie virus. 

 

Option B. Molluscum contagiosum: Pearly white, wart-like umbilicated papules seen due to infection by Pox virus.

 

 

 

Option C. Impetigo: It is of 2 types:

 

  • Bullous – S. aureus
  • Non-bullous – S. aureus and Streptococcus. Golden-yellow or honey coloured crust seen.
     

 

Educational Objective:

 

Herpes labialis is identified as condition characterized by recurrent clusters of vesicles on the lips, caused by the herpes simplex virus, and distinguish it from other vesicular or pustular lesions such as herpangina, molluscum contagiosum, and impetigo.

 

References

Rook's Textbook of Dermatology - 9th Edition - Volume I, Chapter 25 Page no 25.12, 25.17-19, 25.20

Fitzpatrick’s Dermatology 9th edition Page no 2721

questions.text: What type of joint is formed between the costal cartilages of the 8th and 9th ribs as they articulate with the 7th rib? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Synovial joint

 

The interchondral joint between the attachment of the 8th and 9th rib with the 7th rib is a synovial joint.

 

  • Synovial joints are characterized by the presence of a synovial cavity containing synovial fluid, which lubricates the joint and allows for a wide range of movement.
  • While costovertebral joints are typically not classified as synovial joints, some costovertebral joints do have a limited degree of synovial joint characteristics, especially in the upper thoracic region.
  • While the costal cartilages themselves are cartilaginous structures, the joints between the 5th to 9th costal cartilages are specifically synovial in nature.
     

Joints in the thoracic cavity are of the following types:

 

  • Synarthrosis- A fibrous band of tissue connects the structures. E.g., 1st sternocostal joint
  • Synchondrosis - primary cartilaginous joints. E.g., costochondral joints
  • Symphysis - secondary cartilaginous joints. E.g., manubriosternal and xiphisternal joints
  • Synovial joints - the presence of these help the thoracic cavity expand during inspiration. E.g.:
    • Interchondral joint
    • Sternocostal joint
    • Costovertebral joint
    • Costotransverse joint

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fibrocartilaginous Joint:

 

  • Fibrocartilaginous joints are characterized by the presence of fibrocartilage, a type of cartilage that contains both fibrous and cartilaginous components.
  • Examples of fibrocartilaginous joints include the intervertebral discs in the spine and the pubic symphysis in the pelvis. These joints allow for limited movement and provide support and shock absorption.

 

Option B. Symphyseal Joint:

 

  • Symphyseal joints are a specific type of cartilaginous joint where two bones are joined by a broad, flat disc of fibrocartilage. These joints are typically immovable or have limited movement.
  • The pubic symphysis, mentioned earlier, is a common example of a symphyseal joint.

 

Option D. Fibrous Joint:

 

  • Fibrous joints are characterized by the presence of fibrous connective tissue between bones. They are immovable or allow for very limited movement.
  • Examples of fibrous joints include the sutures of the skull and the gomphosis joint between the teeth and their sockets.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 25-year-old young male who was a tattoo artist was brought dead to the casualty under mysterious circumstances. His girlfriend reported he had a large tattoo on his right hand, but this was not found on examination. Which structure should be examined to get more idea of the same? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lymph nodes

 

The ink used for making a tattoo mark is transported through lymph to the regional lymph nodes. Thus, if there is natural / iatrogenic tattoo removal the lymph nodes must be examined.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Liver: The liver is involved in the detoxification and metabolism of substances, but it is not directly related to the transport or storage of tattoo ink.

 

Option C. Spleen: The spleen filters blood and is involved in immune responses, but it does not play a role in the transport or storage of tattoo ink.

 

Option D. Skin: The skin is the primary site where tattoos are applied. However, in the case of a removed tattoo, the skin may not provide useful information about the former presence of the tattoo.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Examining the regional lymph nodes can reveal traces of tattoo ink even if the tattoo itself is no longer visible on the skin, providing useful forensic evidence.

questions.text: A crumpled tissue paper appearance and pancytopenia are seen in which enzyme defect? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Glucocerebrosidase

 

 

Gaucher's disease is characterized by the deficiency of the enzyme glucocerebrosidase (also known as beta-glucosidase). This enzyme defect leads to the accumulation of glucocerebroside within lysosomes of macrophages, resulting in the formation of Gaucher cells. These cells exhibit a characteristic "crumpled tissue paper" appearance due to the fibrillary material within their cytoplasm.

 

Gaucher’s disease is also associated with clinical manifestations such as pancytopenia, hepatosplenomegaly, and bone pain, especially in the long bones. The mnemonic "ouch, ouch, Gaucher" helps recall the painful symptoms and the use of crumpled tissue paper appearance of cells seen in this condition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Alpha galactosidase: This enzyme deficiency is associated with Fabry's disease, not Gaucher’s disease. Fabry's disease presents with symptoms like angiokeratomas, neuropathic pain, and kidney complications, but it does not show crumpled tissue paper cells.

 

Option B. Alpha glucosidase: This enzyme is deficient in Pompe disease, which primarily affects muscle tissues leading to cardiomyopathy and muscle weakness. It does not cause the crumpled tissue paper appearance of cells.

 

Option C. Beta galactosidase: Deficiency of this enzyme leads to Krabbe's disease, characterized by globoid cells, not the crumpled tissue paper appearance. This disorder primarily affects the nervous system, causing severe neurodegeneration.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gaucher's disease is caused by a deficiency of glucocerebrosidase, leading to the characteristic crumpled tissue paper appearance of cells and clinical findings such as pancytopenia and bone pain.
